Yes. Getting off – I mean I'm just repeating what I said before. We were selling products before below cost, so we've stopped selling them. They had high average sale price in them, so that's why your sales drop and your profit moves up somewhat. High/low is a very interesting pricing strategy. And if you understand the DNA of it, which is very complex, getting to an everyday low price to consumers that they trust actually can push volumes up. And that's what we've seen -
And margins.

And pushes margins up as well. What I'm not telling you is what point in the high/low I sat on. It's just that I'm sitting on the best possible price I can deliver to consumers that they like to the point that it drives volume. And when you get the right price and you drive volume, you get a significant increase in dollar margins.

The two reductions in the cost of doing business really happened about a year ago and are starting to flow through more significantly now. One's in the supply chain. The Kmart supply chain was hugely over-invested in and so we're getting the benefits from that. And the non-store costs that we mentioned before.
Greg, we took out – how many people, we took out a significant number of people from the Kmart head office about 12 months ago.
Yeah.
Hundreds.
Yeah.
All right, well you know what the auditors say, watch out for large and unusual movements. So this is large and unusual, but congratulations.
Thanks.

Ian, can I just ask you about these non-value items, these KVIs that you're working in your communications with customers. Coles seems to have a very communication strategy to Woolworths. So I'm just wondering is this the go forward strategy? Does it have to evolve? Does it have to change? If market conditions change would you change what your communications are to customers or this is where you're going and where you have to stay?

I think the customers are always interested in value delivery and they'll look at across a basket of shops. So how we communicate will vary depending on where we think their leanings tend to at certain moments in time. So where there are opportunities to demonstrate value through KVIs, we will see that opportunity. But our Christmas campaign was more broadly based around Coles' home brand, house brand and all the differences that we put into our Coles Finest range.

We had a number of different new product developments there in our fresh food areas through the free range turkeys and additional hams that we did. But we operated even the basic products like mince pies with better products and better value than last year. So there's no one aspect to the strategy, Greg. It actually is looking at individual moments in time and seeing what we believe best appeals to consumers.
So from where you sit, is there a price war?

I think you've got to look at the difference between sort of rhetoric and reality really. There have been a number of different protestations on whether prices are coming down or not. Competitors are talking about prices lower than last year, which can broadly reflect what's happened in the marketplace. Many of them are reflected by changes in cost structures at suppliers or even reductions in levies from the government.

So they tend to reflect what's happened in the industry anyway in many instances. Our deflation level has been a genuine one and we are looking to invest and drive value. And it's not just about price on KVIs. Other areas of the business have seen fairly significant deflation particularly in fruit and veg where certain product categories and products have seen deflation of up to 25%. So it's about maintaining a strong competitive position.
Okay. And I may have missed this but did you call out what the Wesfarmers' calculation of CPI was in your comp?
No, we didn't.
Are you going to call it out?
In terms of the way our inflation is calculated?
No, no. What was your number because your number is not directly comparable, just wondering what your number is.
There's a number in there Greg.
There is?
You're talking about Coles' inflation number on quarter one and quarter two.
Yes.
Slide 14.
Overall it was 0.9% which is broadly flat in the first half and about 1.6 in the second.
Okay. Just a final question, you haven't given us a map of Australia with all these store counts and space. Could we at least have your space for Coles?
It's in the supplementary pack I think, Greg.
All right, okay, cheers. Thanks.
Your next question will come from David Cooke from RBS. Please go ahead.

Hi, team. A couple of quick questions if I may, this one is for Guy. If I have a look at your performance in Kmart, can you give us an indication as to what percentage of your sales you've eliminated because they were non-profitable or extremely low profit and therefore have been able to replace with higher profit sales?

And supplementary to that, how far through the process are you on doing that? Is that now complete and we're looking at in effect a clean sales line going forward? Or is that only halfway through complete so you'd expect to see the same sort of impact coming through in the second half?

Yeah, I actually won't comment on what percentage that we've exited versus added on because clearly we're moving metrics around all over the place in the business. All I can say is that we're probably about three quarters of the way through reengineering all of this because now as I mentioned, we're now moving into a new phase which we launched to our consumers about Expect Change.

So this Expect Change piece is very critical for us because we need to – with all the changes that have happened in the stores, with faster service, friendlier service, clearer aisles and easier to shop, we need to be telling – reigniting with consumers that used to visit us to come back. So that's why in my outlook I've talked about a moderate sales growth that I expect at least in this quarter that will be in the positive.
Okay. What – was the majority of your margin expansion gross margin or cost of doing business related?

It was in both areas. The gross margin improves because of the – because of what I articulated about the exiting unprofitable products. And the costs of doing business reduction maybe was about a third of it.
And Launa, in your area, again the margin of improvement there, was that fairly equally weighted or is that mainly CODB?

It was a number of things as I've said because we did a lot of work on our supply chain which saw that improve our margin, but that is still going to cost to the business as such. So, it was a number of things.
No indication as to roughly whether it was more one than the other?

No. As I just said though, don't forget it was the swing as well into the higher margined items that we were selling which did benefit us, as it moved away from electronics and that type of product that was low margin more into apparel which is our core competency which does traditionally have higher margins.

Okay. This one is for Stewart. Stewart, your expansion of your met coal production capabilities, are you expecting to sell all of that to existing customers? Or are you going to have to develop new customer relationships to move that extra volume?

It's fair to say that we've forward sold the additional volume to take it up to the 8 to 8.5 million tons of export metallurgical coal. The majority of that has gone to our existing customers in North Asia. There's one or two additional customers we've brought on line. But, essentially our philosophy has been very much to look after existing customers before we look outside. So, essentially it's gone to our existing customer base.
Great, thanks for that.
Thanks David.
Oh sorry, just one final. When you go – this one's for Ian. Ian, you were talking about inflation. Did I hear you correctly in saying second half you're expecting inflation or deflation?
I said it would probably continue to be lower levels of inflation.
Okay, thank you.
Obviously deflation is a very low level of inflation, but I didn't commit to that.
Oh, okay, thank you.
Your next question will come from Andrew McLennan from Commonwealth Bank. Please go ahead.

Hi guys. Gee, this turnaround thing seems pretty easy, when are you going to have a crack at Fosters? No ideas? Look just in terms of the potential expansion – sorry, the expansion in Curragh, I'm just wondering whether you've got any further idea in terms of the timing across the FY '11 year of that volume through put. You've provided updated guidance for FY '10 of 6.3 to 6.8. Can you provide any further clarity in terms of FY '11?
What we've said there is that the expansion will come online late calendar year 2011. So, Q4 2011 is the timing for the additional volume coming online.
So, we'll talk about sort of volume expectations for the 10 or 11 year at the briefing day in May
In May, yes.

Sure, okay. And I just wanted to go back to one of the very first questions asked by Phil and just towards Ian. I'm not sure whether he mentioned growth in the new format stores. Obviously, it's not a large enough store base to move the needle on total sales for Coles. But I was just wondering how the sales growth was going there with the reformatting?

Yeah. I mean the stores have new concepts in them, the sales growth in those stores continues to perform well. We're seeing improvements in fresh participation, in customer perceptions of freshness and value in service well ahead of the chain. So, it's an encouraging sales story.
Okay, that's all from me. Thanks very much.
Thanks.
And your next question will come from Richard Barwick from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Hi Richard and team. A question for Ian for starters. How much of the deflation that we saw across the half is the result of price reinvestment and how much is actually natural deflation in the supply chain?

I haven't split that out, but what we're doing as a program is ensuring we've got a strongly competitive position in the marketplace. And we're investing in price to drive volume and deliver better value to customers. And customers are responding to that by shopping with us more often and spending more with us.

There's been a – I guess in the long term there's been a few – there's been perception issues from consumers towards Coles' pricing. Have you – do you feel like that you've got consumers thinking about Coles' pricing the way that you'd like them to?

I think that supermarkets generally, there's more work that needs to be done. I think that the level of trust there is in supermarket pricing in Australia it is lower than it is in other countries. And I think that what we've got to do is to try and have more openness and transparency in our pricing policy. That's why we moved to our uniform pricing policy, which we announced a few weeks ago to try and make sure that consumers accept this sort of consistency across individual states. And customers have responded well to that particular move.
How long do you think it will take Ian before you're in a position or perhaps where the consumers are thinking and believing in the price proposition as you describe it?
I think you have to work on it continually. I don't think you'll ever be there completely. Consumers will obviously look to seek out value and they've got every right to do so.

Okay. You mentioned or at least it was listed on the slide pack, increasing competition as part of the Coles' outlook. I don't think you really touched on it in much detail though and how much of the price reductions that we've just seen from Woolworths plays into that comment? I'm hoping you could explain that in a little bit more detail please.

I mean I think there's a broader competitive set out there. I think everybody is mindful of the fact that the consumer is becoming more value focused. I think that last year it was marked in terms of consumer consideration in that regard, when there was risk of the recession.

And although that was narrowly avoided and there's broader levels of confidence, I think that once consumers have sought out value they maintain that habit. And I think all retailers have to be mindful for that. I think that there's a certain degree of confusion over the Woolworths position. I think that in their announcement they said that their inflation number is 1.6%.

So, in their sales level that's about $300 million of price rises against 120 million of claimed price reductions. So, I don't know whether they are putting three times the prices up as they're bringing down or not. You'll have to ask them. But our position is a genuine one where, based on our calculations, that we're investing in price to deliver better value. And that's where the 0.9% deflation comes from. It's real.
Yep, I understand. The 40 renewal stores that are on the ground now, how many of those are new stores and how many are refurbishments of an existing store?
Broadly 50-50.
Okay. I think you'd given some color before around numbers targeting 50 renewal stores for the end of financial year '10?
That's about right, yeah.
Yeah, so I mean – it would make for a pretty lazy second half with only ten more?

I think you've got to remember in the second half you've got other factors that prevail. We're coming out of the Christmas period and into Easter and a lot of it is a question of timing of what stores are coming out of the ground. So it's a balance across the financial year. I mean, 50 at this stage in the turnaround, I think Asda had less than 10 at the same point in time. And it's not a rush on numbers. It's more ensuring that we've got the right concepts working to deliver the right return.

We've seen that we're getting good consumer responses from that. We've got stores in each state and across different demographics, so it's giving us real insights into what's working. And in some respects there are some elements of renewal that we can lift out of the renewal stores and roll back across the fleet. And we're doing that in our health and beauty concept, for example.
Okay. So, sticking with the 50 for this year and sticking also with the 100 for next year?

I think when we said we would get – during the course of 2011, we'd anticipate getting up to a – if you're at full pace you would be up to around about 100. But I think that what we've got to recognize in this it's not just about physical renewal. It involves a lot of changes in terms of philosophy in the stores, on people, the product offering as well and a broad range of concepts as well. So, we'll be progressively broadening the program. But, we're looking very carefully at the returns that we're getting out of the stores before committing to broader levels of roll out from where we are now.
There's a lot of other things going on too, Richard, like the easy ordering rollout which is very significant as well.
Yes, I understand. In terms of driving like-for-like sales growth, do you see increased fresh participation as the biggest driver?

No. I think that it's certainly been a benefit. But we've seen as I mentioned earlier on one of the previous questions, we're seeing positive growth in each areas of our store, whether it be in core grocery and also in fresh food. We're also seeing good sales improvements in liquor as well. That's the encouraging thing about the program at the moment that we're seeing momentum in each aspect of our business.

Yes. And a question for Guy now. Guy, obviously we talked a lot about what you've done on gross margins, category mix and smarter promotions et cetera. Would you say you're actually starting to win some customers back from Target and Big W yet?

I've always had the view that my competitors are a lot more closer to the K-Mart stores than what all of you have referred to in mentioning Target and Big W mainly because of the walking distance between the three brands. So, I still feel the same way about that, is that each -- my businesses have a lot of competitors right next to them. And I believe that if we focus on price, products that consumers need, and make sure that the team members deliver great superior service, that we will get a bigger percentage of consumers coming back to K-Mart as well as getting them to spend some more. So, it'll take some time, but I'm still of this firm belief that my competitors are within a three minute walk of where my current K-Marts are.
Okay. So how – what does that mean in terms of how long do we have to wait until we start to see some positive like-for-like sales growth?
We look forward to talking to you in May or April.

Okay, that sounds promising. And final question for Terry. Obviously we've seen some big licks come out of working capital. How much more of that should we expect to see before it settles down and normalizes?

Yeah, I think I'll reiterate again that – to look at the first half as there is a bit of seasonality in those numbers. So, that's the first point I think that you've got to consider. Then we look at the turnaround performance particularly in K-Mart and Coles. We've always had a strong working capital focus across all of Wesfarmers and Launa's and the management team there is – have been focusing on all of the things that Wesfarmers would've focused on in any case. So, when we look at the turnaround, there was obviously some opportunities in Coles and K-Mart. I think we've moved very quickly at a lot of that. I think the reality is that increasingly we'll probably see some slowing in working capital release because you get to a point where it becomes harder. So, – but we will – if we reflect back well in excess of where we thought we'd be on working capital release. So, we're pleased where we've got to today and it's one of those things you keep working hard at.

Yeah, when I think back to the original documentation you guys put out when you first bought Coles, you're well ahead of those sort of numbers. So, I guess that's the question, if we'd see any more periods of the big changes or if it's time to settle down into I guess a more normal pattern?
Time will tell.
All right, thank you very much.
Thanks Richard.
Your next question will come from David Errington from Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.
Hi guys.
Hi David. I thought you must have been asleep.

Well, I nearly did. I forget what I was going to ask – when I look at the – I don't want to be a killjoy on the performance of Target and K-Mart because clearly outstanding results. But when I look at the retail businesses – when you look at Bunnings, Bunnings has sales growths around that 14% and EBIT growth's 14%. Coles volume growth is around seven percentage now and you're getting 12% to 13% EBIT growth and Office works was around that 10% sales growth and 10% EBIT growth. And they're both businesses I think Ian reiterated many times, reinvesting in value for the customers.

Now I understand when you look at Target, you're looking at 2 to 3 or 4% sales growth and 30% EBIT growth and K-Mart negative sales growth and 100% EBIT growth. And the things that were cited were areas cited that just about every retailer in the world is doing, supply chain, cutting unprofitable lines, selling more profitable items et cetera, et cetera. I suppose where I'm getting to here is I'm very concerned that maybe you're cutting the mustard a little bit. I mean, the last retailer I saw generate negative sales growth but with a big profit increase was Myer and they've got a bit of a world of trouble at the moment. I'm just worried because I haven't heard Launa or I haven't heard Guy mention once that they're reinvesting in the value for their customers. It has all been about cutting unprofitable items, cutting costs and basically back-pocketing the outcome of that. So, that's my observation. I'm concerned about that. I was just wondering if you could comment on it.

David let me just kick-off and then I'll quickly hand on to Guy and Launa. I think there's a big difference between those two businesses. And I'll let Launa answer for Target. But K-Mart, 6 or 12 months ago, everyone was talking about what a dog of a business K-Mart was.
You were as well.

But what we did was we put in place a very good management team that's now delivering on our strategy. And so, while some people might be surprised with the pace of improvement, no one should be surprised that that business can improve. And in fact you've just got to look at some other businesses that have done that. So, I think where we've taken – while the performance of K-Mart is very pleasing, you're looking at the overall context of where it's come from.

I can remember you saying to me, Richard and others that you were looking at Myer's strategy and K-Mart was going to follow a Myer's strategy. Now Myer's strategy was to really take costs out, not really grow sales. And right now it's probably fair to say that that business is really stagnating and struggling to go forward. I'm just wondering at the end of the day, you've got to try to improve the underlying business. I mean you can cut costs and bank a big profit, I suppose the issue is the sustainability of that and that's where I think most of the questions today are trying to get at.
Yeah.
Have you improved the underlying business or have you just basically made it more profitable; it may only last for a short period of time?

I don't think there's any question that we are improving the underlying business of K-Mart significantly. And while I don't want to comment on other businesses, I think if you look at where Myer was when it was sold off from the Coles Group to where it is now, I think it's a much stronger business as well. And my comments about K-Mart in relation to Myer were that there were a lot of things that were done in K-Mart that could be improved on, and with the appropriate attention, focus and good management and focus from our staff, we would be able to achieve, and we're on that path, and I actually think that path's got a long way to go.

And on Target, as I said, I think people get into a paradigm of thinking that this is – business is good and this is all it can do. I actually think what we've shown in the first half and we've had some things go our way, but what we've shown in the first half is that Target's actually got lots of further potential as well. I'll let Guy and Launa talk about specifics.

Yeah. So David, I don't know whether to thank you for your misguidance on what you thought was going to happen. But I want to be very clear about K-Mart. Whilst it's a complex problem that's occurred over the last decade, this $4 billion business, unlike all the businesses you refer to that had a cost-cutting strategy to improve profit, this business had no profit. Its net income was zero. So, whilst the results are pleasing for the first six months, they're still in third place compared to the two businesses that all of you keep comparing me to, which is Target and Big W. I'm still third and there's still a long, long way to go.

Their other two models have got similar revenue with EBITs between 6% to 10%. So, I've got a long way to go. So, our business was focused on three things: discovery, working out what was wrong, and what we needed to address. The second phase was renewal. And that's a little bit like before you start growing the business, we needed to fix up the DNA of the organization that was built over many, many years and was not acceptable. So, the renewal part was resetting the foundations before you start putting a glossy paint to make it look good.

So whilst I know that sales growth is absolutely important, I did announce, if you were listening earlier, that we've now moved into phase three which is growth. So they're all going together, and one isn't, one isn't – not reliant on the other. They all need to continue on in a forward motion. And as I said, my expectations over the next quarter is that you'll start to see positive sales momentum. But the resetting of the business will clearly throw up some challenges in regards to the profitability that we achieved in the first half, may not be as significant in the second half.
And Launa, is it – because I must say again both of you, neither of you actually said what Ian said, reinvesting in the value for the customer. Neither of you actually said that.

All right. Well David, let me just say I might not have said it, but we in fact are doing that. In the last few months, we've been very aware that competition have been lowering their prices, and we have in turn responded, particularly in categories where we felt we were being attacked. In fact going forward we are starting to do further price reinvestment, and we have called that out. And if you'd been into our stores over the last few months, you would have actually seen categories where we had dropped the price, where we've put new lower price. And we are continuing to do that and to reinvest, and strongly.

The thing about summer was that our products, particularly in ladies wear, are well priced. Our whole strategy is to be 20 to 30% less than specialty stores, and that's what we are. We keep a very close eye on what the costs and prices are in both the Myer's, Jackie E and any of those other retailers that we deem to be competitors. And we therefore make sure our prices are adjusted accordingly. Going forward, we will continue to do that. We are also aware of what Big W does, particularly on the lower price points, and we have made sure that we have strongly moved volume into those lower price points, particularly in children's wear.

So David, I might not have said it, but we are very aware of what's happening out there in the market and responding accordingly. Look, for all the great profit, we were disappointed with the sales result, but it was what we expected. We were up against a very tough – we had had a good sales growth the previous Christmas, we were up over 6% if you recall. We had to now go against that and we planned it well.

We didn't have a great December and we anticipated it. What we did do though is we managed our stocks and managed our costs. I am cautious for the next half, and I called that out quite clearly to you because we did have a good winter, and it wasn't product that gave us a good profit.
It was a great result.

David, I just want to say one thing; I did say it, so maybe you weren't listening properly. I said expect change at K-Mart with faster and friendlier service, expect clearer and cleaner aisles, expect lower prices and expect longer trading hours. And if you didn't hear that; watch TV. It's also on the TV where I'm giving that commitment to consumers right across Australia and New Zealand, and on billboards if you don't watch TV, on the road.
Well I hope the consumers watch it, because then we'll see greater sales growth, so I'm sure they will.
Look forward to seeing you in May.

And just finally, moving on to one last question on Resources, Stewart. The hedging book I notice, I think you've got about U.S. $330 million locked in. And if rumors be true or if speculation be true, that will probably only hedge about 1.5 million tons of coal in the coming year. When do you think that you might have to start rolling that book out, because at the moment Curragh is pretty – in an un-hedged situation for currency?
Yes, clearly we recognize that and over the next few months as certainty comes out there in terms of coal prices we'll be hedging to cover our policy over the next three to four years.

David, it's Terry here. We've got a policy that we still abide by, which is on a declining basis, an increasing percentage of Curragh's hedge book. So we will look at that. But I think in the next – over the next year, our hedging will be fine.
Great results, guys. Launa and Guy certainly took the heat off Ian today, so well done.
Thanks David.
Thanks David.
And let me just say one thing David, don't be thinking you're going to get 12.8% EBIT margin for the second half.
I'll never underestimate you, Launa, you know that.
Thanks David.
Your next question will come from Andrew Harrington from Patersons. Please go ahead.
We will need to wrap up shortly, so. Hi, Andrew.

Okay, I'll be quick. So good afternoon. I'm going to ask this question of Stewart. What's the CapEx rollout over the next few quarters, in particular for Curragh? And what's the profile production over the next, more specifically FY '11, but if you can give an outline of the total production levels going forward?

Well, I'll give guidance on next year's production and sales at the May Investor Relations. Clearly I've given guidance for the second half of this current financial year, and that's 6.2 to – 6.3 to 6.8. In terms of capital, we've clearly announced some major capital expenditures over the last 12 months. Blackwater Creek is finished in December. It rolled into our first half capital expenditure, which is about $107 million for the first half.

Second half of this financial year is going to be a further $200 million plus. Clearly the bulk of that will be in and around the Curragh expansion which we announced in November, and that's $286 million. There's a big chunk of stay-in-business capital associated with running our businesses. So we do have a reasonable capital program over the next couple of years, and it's all about driving growth through our businesses. So, and it's an exciting time for us. In terms of the – I suppose the expansion of Curragh, we are particularly excited in terms of that because we've managed to get that expansion away probably ahead of the pack in terms of other expansions for the coal industry. We've been able to capture what we think is very, very competitive infrastructure and capital prices. And if the market goes the way we think it will be, we'll be able to capture some of that with higher metallurgical prices going forward.
And does that include all the allocation of rail and port? That's all locked away for the expansion?
Yes, we've got sufficient rail and port capacity to meet that 8 to 8.5 million tons per year.
Okay. Thanks a lot.
I think we got one more question?
Your final question will come from Daniel Broeren from CLSA. Please go ahead.
Afternoon everybody. Launa, just one question for you, what sort of investment would be required to bring the design function in-house, and just an idea of the timing for that as well?

Well, let me just say we are actually underway with our new process and we already do have designers within our business. What we have looked to do is to further increase the number, both here and in Hong Kong. And the idea is that that will be funded as we start to consolidate our suppliers and be more meaningful to them. And we are also expecting to have costs come away from our suppliers as we undertake the design work in-house, because the whole idea is we will give them a design pack which has got all the QA specifications and everything that will be handed over to them. We've also – looking to be purchasing some of our own fabrications which will enable us as well to look to get better prices. This is not going to happen immediately. It's commenced, but you'll only really start to see the benefits of it unfold next year.

And we're actually in a tricky stage at the moment, because we're still working in the old way of working, in other words the way Target used to work. But yet we're starting to do far more forward planning to make this effective from really the next calendar year.
Okay. So basically we're going to see some GP margin benefit from this strategy going on from the next calendar year plus currency benefits still to come in the next fiscal year?
Sorry Andrew you broke up there. I didn't get that.
Sorry, can you hear me now?
Sorry, yes. Can you just repeat what you said? I didn't quite get that.
Okay. So there're going to be some GP margin benefits coming through from this strategy in the next calendar year?
Well, not in this financial year.

That's right, next financial year plus some currency benefits coming through in the next financial year as well. So is it fair to assume that the average margin on an annual basis for Target can increase beyond 12 – beyond current levels?

No, I wouldn't like to say that. This is called a whole strategy that's unfolding in the sense of how are we going to be going to market. Our actual strategy of differentiated products stays the same. It's the manner in which we're trying to achieve that that has been changing, that's going to be changed. And I wouldn't like to go out there and make any forecasts at this stage.

Okay, thanks for that. And one last question on Chemicals and Fertilizer. Just looking back at last year's half year presentation deck, it was mentioned that the Varanus costs impacted EBIT by about 50 million in the first half, and this year's result has been a $27 million EBIT contribution. Can you just talk through the difference there and why we haven't seen all that contribution come back?

Yeah. Well, we said that we had a very good Chemicals half and returned to normal gas supplies. So it would be fair to say that the value that we put in the previous half has returned to profitability, which then obviously leaves you with fertilizer, which we said we had a pretty significant write-down of 25 million. And you could assume from the comments that the margins in Fertilizer have been extremely low in the last half as well. So effectively, in broad terms as I said you've got a decline in fertilizer earnings, reasonably significantly and you've got an increase in chemicals earnings reasonably significantly. And overall we're above last year but it's – that's what drove it.
Okay. Now that makes sense. Thanks for that. Cheers.
Thank you all. We look forward to seeing you all in the not too distant future
